name: Hjálparfoss - The Helping Waterfall
description: Hjálparfoss, whose name translates to "Helping Falls" or "Helper Falls," is a uniquely beautiful twin waterfall in South Iceland where two rivers—the Fossá and the Þjórsá (Iceland's longest river)—converge and cascade side by side at approximately 45-degree angles to each other before merging into a single flow. This unusual Y-shaped waterfall configuration creates a distinctive visual composition where two separate white curtains of water tumble simultaneously over dark volcanic rock ledges into a shared pool below, framed by the columnar basalt and ancient lava formations from which they emerge. The waterfall's height is modest at approximately 10-12 meters, but what it lacks in vertical drama it more than compensates for in scenic charm and geological interest. Hjálparfoss sits within the Þjórsárdalur valley surrounded by the massive Þjórsárhraun lava field, which was created by an eruption in the Veiðivötn fissure system approximately 8,700 years ago and represents the largest known lava flow on Earth since the end of the last Ice Age. The lava at Hjálparfoss has weathered and eroded over millennia into fascinating formations including hexagonal basalt columns, caves, and unusual rock shapes that visitors can explore on short walks around the waterfall area. The name "Helping Falls" derives from the historical importance of this river confluence point: shepherds driving sheep between highland summer pastures and lowland winter pastures would gather at this spot where the rivers were shallow enough to ford safely.
